section_purpose: To present the fundamental DPLL (Davis-Putnam-Logemann-Loveland) recursive backtracking algorithm for solving SAT problems, serving as the base framework that the paper's guided heuristics will later augment.
key_points: The algorithm takes a Boolean formula as input and recursively searches for a satisfying assignment.
It first simplifies the formula using unit propagation and pure literal elimination.
The core of the algorithm is a branching step where it picks a literal and explores both possible truth assignments.
It returns SAT if the formula simplifies to empty (satisfied) and UNSAT if a contradiction (empty clause) is found.

algorithms: DPLL recursive backtracking algorithm with unit propagation and pure literal elimination
formulas: Formula representation: φ as input and recursively updated

dependencies: Assumes familiarity with Boolean SAT problems and basic SAT solving concepts (likely from Section 1.1 Background)
reproducibility_notes: The core DPLL algorithm logic, including the recursive function SOLVE
The order of operations: simplification (unit propagation, pure literal elimination) then branching
The definition of the helper functions UNIT-PROPAGATION, PURE-LITERAL-ELIMINATION, and PICK-LITERAL (the latter is the focus of the paper's guidance)
